repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Second Local Government
            Development Project (LGDP II)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Local Government
            Development Project (LGDP II) in Uganda were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately unsatisfactory. Lessons learned included:
            policy reversals can cause serious damage to otherwise
            significant project outcomes, and are difficult to counter.
            District proliferation or reduction in un-earmarked funding
            or local governments' rights to raise revenues need to
            be monitored closely as they could be an early signal of
            policy reversal. Monitoring should be focused on outcome in
            addition to process indicators and unified across sectors.
            Decentralization is not a sector, while it was treated as
            such in Uganda with a sector working group, a sector
            investment plan and specific donor support. Decentralization
            of service delivery affects all sectors of the economy and
            should be supported in a harmonized way across sectors and
            donor programs. Many conditional grants to Local Governments
            are funded through donor programs. A fully decentralized
            sector allocation, supported through government budgets,
            requires a change in the way donors allocate funds across
            sectors within a given country as such allocations cannot be
            determined a priori any more if the choice of sectors is
            truly delegated to Local Governments and communities. This
            is often incompatible with the development cooperation
            frameworks of bilateral donors, or the sector-specific teams
            and earmarked funds of multilaterals, that work in tandem
            with line ministries in developing countries like Uganda.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Second Local Government
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Local Government
            Development Project (LGDP II) in Uganda were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Lessons learned
            included:  a core of LGDP II focus was on the transfer,
            monitoring and accounting for regular Local Development
            Grants (LDG) and Capacity Building Grants (CBG) to local
            governments. The grants were contingent on the local
            governments passing an annual performance assessment. LGDP
            II was designed to fund the two grants and annual
            assessments for the first three years of the four year
            project period. It was believed that if the two grants and
            local government performance were indeed critical,
            Government of Uganda (GoU) will begin funding and managing
            them from its own resources. This materialized in the third
            year of the project when GoU began funding both grants from
            its own budget, included them in the Medium Term Expenditure
            Framework (MTEF) and mainstreamed the annual assessment of
            local governments through its own Inspectorate Department.
            Building capacity requires much more than providing training
            and conducting workshops: getting fiscal transfers right is
            just one part of ensuring effective decentralization.
            Building institutional and human capacity within central as
            well as local governments is equally important and which
            cannot be achieved by depending on training events and
            workshops alone. LGDP II used multiple approaches including
            active mentoring of local government staff by senior and
            more experienced government personnel who provided hands on
            support to their colleagues, ensuring standardization of
            information flows through the preparation of handbooks and
            guidelines with clear instructions on how to implement new
            procedures, conducting regular assessments to provide follow
            up guidance and feedback. Of course, training was required,
            but instead of contracting out training, LGDP II was
            instrumental in creating a national market for training
            where the local governments procured training from a list of
            accredited private and public training providers who had to
            compete for it. As an unintended consequence, the
            competitive training providers market has also led to the
            creation of a growing local pool of consultants who now
            understand and can respond to the needs of local governments.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Second Local Government
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Second
            Local Government Development Project for Uganda is to
            improve local government institutional performance for
            sustainable, decentralized service delivery. The project
            consists of 5 components.  The first component will support
            the decentralization process through: supporting the
            development of a national Local Government (LG) capacity
            building strategy; strengthening of the human resource
            development functions in LGs; supporting annual workshops;
            establishing an analytical and design basis for the
            development of a decentralization budget support instrument;
            supporting the national assessment system; operationalizing
            the planning guidelines and information systems; auditing
            the accounts of all LLGs for the first two years of the
            Project; and finally activities supporting the improvement
            of the LGs planning and implementation of projects which
            will be funded by the local government development grant
            (component 2).  The second component, local development
            grants, will be funded by an IDA Grant (unlike the other
            components which will come from a credit).  This component
            will continue and extend the financing of local
            infrastructure investment through supporting a system of
            central-local intergovernmental transfers.  The third
            component, local government capacity building will provide
            capacity building grants to LGs.  The fourth component,
            local government revenue enhancement, will finance technical
            assistance at both the policy and operational levels.  The
            final component, support to project implementation, consists
            of activities to support project management, monitoring,
            evaluation and audits of the accounts of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Second Local Government
            Development Program (LGDP) Project : environmental and
            social management framework (ESMF) report

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for
            Uganda's Second Local Government Development Program
            Project provides a framework to establish the screening
            process mechanism that identifies potential environmental
            and social impacts of sub-projects and to address them by
            incorporating the relevant mitigation measures into
            sub-project design. The main feature of this mechanism
            requires the sub-project implementers to screen their
            sub-projects at the preparation stage using the screening
            form in Annex 1 of this report and the revised environmental
            and social checklist to identify potential adverse
            effects/impacts. Sub-projects requiring individual
            environmental and social impact assessments (ESIAs) are
            those costing US$100,000 and/or sub-projects involving new
            roads, incorporating use of hazardous chemicals and managing
            solid, liquid, or medical wastes. The use of the results of
            the ESIA would be how these sub-projects identify their
            adverse effects which would then be adequately mitigated in
            the sub-project designs before submission for review and
            approval. This Environmental and Social Management Framework
            (ESMF) report assesses the capacity at the District and
            Lower Local Governments to implement the proposed screening
            process and mitigation measures, including the provision of
            support to communities in cases of community-managed
            sub-projects, and makes recommendations, including training
            needs and cost. The ESMF assessed the content, use, and
            effectiveness of the existing Environment and Social
            Checklist prepared under the project; and recommended a
            significant overhaul to make it simpler and easier to use at
            all levels of the local government system, but especially at
            the level of the Technical Planning Committee (TPC) and the
            Project Management Committee (PMC) levels.
